dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: I'd love to hear about your apprenticeship in Paris.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: Ah, Paris. I was just a young lad, around 16 or 17. I remember the early mornings, the smell of fresh bread filling the streets. My mentor was a tough man, Monsieur Lefevre. He didn't take it easy on us, but he taught me everything I needed to know about baking.

sentence_annotations.text: Ah, Paris. I was just a young lad, around 16 or 17.
My mentor was a tough man, Monsieur Lefevre.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: It sounds like Monsieur Lefevre had a big impact on your life. What was it like working under him?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: He was a hard taskmaster, no doubt. But he was fair. Everything had to be perfect with him. He would make us redo a batch if it wasn't just right. At the time, it was frustrating, but I learned the importance of precision and dedication.

sentence_annotations.text: He was a hard taskmaster, no doubt. But he was fair. Everything had to be perfect with him.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: That must have been hard, but it sounds like it shaped you into the baker you became. So when did things change?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: Things changed when I finished my apprenticeship and decided to try my luck in America. I was around 22, and I wanted to bring the taste of French pastries to New York. It was a big leap, leaving everything I knew behind, but I was determined.

sentence_annotations.text: Things changed when I finished my apprenticeship and decided to try my luck in America.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: What was it like starting out in New York?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: Starting out in New York was a whirlwind. I didn't have much money, just a small space in the Lower East Side. It wasn't easy, the competition was fierce, but the city had an energy that kept me going. I remember waking up before dawn to start baking, trying to recreate the magic of Parisian pastries in a tiny oven.

sentence_annotations.text: Starting out in New York was a whirlwind. I didn't have much money, just a small space in the Lower East Side.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: That sounds like quite the challenge, Pierre. What were some of the biggest hurdles you faced during that time?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: The biggest hurdle was building a customer base. People in New York had different tastes, and convincing them to try my French pastries was tough. I had to adapt some recipes, which was painful because I wanted to stay true to what I learned. Plus, the financial struggle was always there. Rent was high, and there were days I didn't know if I would make enough to keep the doors open.

sentence_annotations.text: The biggest hurdle was building a customer base... I had to adapt some recipes...
Plus, the financial struggle was always there. Rent was high...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: That must have been incredibly stressful, trying to make ends meet while staying true to your craft. Did you ever reach a point where things started to get easier?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: Well, after a couple of years, things did start to improve. Word of mouth was powerful, and the locals began to appreciate the authenticity of my pastries. I remember the first time a customer came in and said my croissants reminded them of Paris; that was a turning point. But just as things were looking up, the unexpected happened – I started losing my sense of smell.

sentence_annotations.text: Well, after a couple of years, things did start to improve. Word of mouth was powerful, and the locals began to appreciate the authenticity of my pastries.
But just as things were looking up, the unexpected happened – I started losing my sense of smell.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: That sounds like a significant turning point. What was it like realizing you were losing your sense of smell?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: It was terrifying. At first, I thought it was just a temporary thing, maybe a cold or allergies. But it didn't go away. Baking relies so much on your senses, especially smell, to judge when things are just right. I felt like I was losing a part of myself.

sentence_annotations.text: It was terrifying. At first, I thought it was just a temporary thing, maybe a cold or allergies. But it didn't go away. Baking relies so much on your senses, especially smell, to judge when things are just right. I felt like I was losing a part of myself.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: That must have been incredibly difficult, Pierre. How did you cope with that change in your life?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: It was tough, no doubt. I had to rely more on my other senses, like touch and sight, to know when the dough was ready or when something was perfectly baked. But it wasn't the same. There was a period where I even considered giving it all up, but I couldn't bring myself to do it. Baking is a part of who I am, and I couldn't just walk away from that. I found ways to adapt, and thankfully, I had a team I trusted to help me with things I could no longer do alone.

sentence_annotations.text: Baking is a part of who I am, and I couldn't just walk away from that.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: It sounds like you've faced quite a few challenges throughout your life. How do you feel looking back on everything now?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: Looking back, it's been a journey, that's for sure. There were moments of doubt and times when I thought I wouldn't make it. But you know, I'm proud of what I've achieved. Losing my sense of smell was a blow, but it taught me resilience. I learned to adapt, to rely on others, and to trust my instincts in other ways. And even though I couldn't smell the bread, I could still see the joy in my customers' faces when they tasted it. That kept me going. Life isn't always perfect, but I wouldn't trade my experiences for anything.

sentence_annotations.text: Looking back, it's been a journey, that's for sure.
Losing my sense of smell was a blow, but it taught me resilience.
And even though I couldn't smell the bread, I could still see the joy in my customers' faces when they tasted it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: Before we finish, Pierre, if you were to pass on one lesson you've learned from your journey to the next generation of bakers or anyone pursuing their passions, what would it be?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: I'd say, don't be afraid of change, and don't be afraid to adapt. Life will throw you curveballs, like losing my sense of smell, but it's how you respond that matters. Stick to what you're passionate about, but also be willing to evolve. And remember, it's not just about you. Rely on others, build a team you trust. You can't do it all alone, and that's okay.

sentence_annotations.text: I'd say, don't be afraid of change, and don't be afraid to adapt. Life will throw you curveballs, like losing my sense of smell, but it's how you respond that matters. Stick to what you're passionate about, but also be willing to evolve. And remember, it's not just about you. Rely on others, build a team you trust. You can't do it all alone, and that's okay.
